Technical Assistance Report
Project Number:  52370-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2020 
Supporting the Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation Institute  
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
  COVID-19  –  coronavirus disease 
  KPS  –  knowledge product and service 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  RCI  –  regional cooperation and integration 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  Shixin Chen, Operations 1 
Director General  Werner Liepach, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Director  Safdar Parvez, Regional Cooperation and Operations 
Coordination Division (CWRC), CWRD 
   
Team leader  Lyaziza Sabyrova, Principal Regional Economist, CWRC, 
CWRD 
Team members  Mary Margareth M. Bernus, Associate Financial Management 
Officer, Office of the Director General, Portfolio, Results, 
Safeguards and Gender Unit, CWRD 
Licel D. Calderon-Tanquintic, Senior Operations Assistant, 
CWRC, CWRD 
Ursula Lagan, Counsel, Office of the General Counsel 
Honey May L. Manzano-Guerzon, Associate Knowledge 
Management Officer, CWRC, CWRD 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

CONTENTS 
 
Page

III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  3

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  regional  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  further 
institutional development of the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Institute, 
an  intergovernmental  organization  that  aims  to  contribute to the  CAREC  Program  through 
knowledge generation and capacity building.1 The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been 
supporting the CAREC Institute from its inception, and this TA will build on previous ADB support 
provided to the CAREC Institute.2 This TA will (i) strengthen the CAREC Institute’s institutional 
capacity and financial sustainability, (ii) enhance the quality of the CAREC Institute’s knowledge 
products and services (KPS), and (iii) invigorate the CAREC Institute’s communication and 
outreach  functions.  The  TA  will  help  realize  the  CAREC  Institute’s  potential  comparative 
advantages and uniqueness.3 
 
2.  The TA is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 and its operational priority of fostering 
regional cooperation and integration (RCI).4 It is also in line with the CAREC Strategy 2030, which 
calls on the CAREC Institute to promote policy dialogue among CAREC countries on key 
economic, social, and governance issues based on value-adding knowledge work.5 This value-
added work has become even more important as CAREC countries fight the coronavirus disease 
(COVID-19) and its socioeconomic implications.6  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Since its establishment, the CAREC Institute has made important progress in all four areas 
of its operations—research, capacity building, knowledge management, and networking and 
partnerships. Together with funding from the People’s Republic of China (PRC), ADB’s previous 
and ongoing TA projects contributed to the establishment and functioning of the CAREC Institute 
in delivering its mandate as a knowledge arm of the CAREC Program. In addition to TA support, 
the ADB team is providing intellectual support to the CAREC Institute’s activities, with regular 
guidance and technical advice from ADB’s Central and West Asia Department and other ADB 
departments and units.7 The CAREC Institute has significantly shored up its institutional capacity.8 
 
1  The CAREC Institute was established in 2006 as a virtual institute; and opened its physical headquarters in March 
2015 in Urumqi, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, the People’s Republic of China (PRC). The Intergovernmental 
Agreement establishing the CAREC Institute outlines its five key functions: (i) conduct strategic research, (ii) provide 
innovative solutions, (iii) disseminate research findings and results, (iv) enhance the capabilities of government 
officials, and (v) develop a network of research institutions in the CAREC region. 
2  ADB.  2012.  Technical  Assistance  for  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation:  Supporting  Capacity 
Development Needs of CAREC 2020. Manila (TA 8301, ongoing until March 2021). Earlier support includes ADB. 
2008. Technical Assistance for Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Institute, 2009–2012. Manila (TA 6488, 
implemented during 2008–2015). 
3  The uniqueness and potential comparative advantage of the CAREC Institute lie in (i) its regional mandate, focus on 
regional cooperation, and coverage of multiple sectors closely linked to CAREC priorities, as opposed to other think 
tanks in CAREC countries that have national mandates and a specific subject focus; (ii) its knowledge base of the 
region, as most CAREC Institute staff are from CAREC member countries and have proven records in research, 
capacity building, and policy analysis; (iii) its intergovernmental status; and (iv) strong and sustained support from 
ADB and the PRC.  
4  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
5  ADB. 2017. CAREC 2030: Connecting the Region for Shared and Sustainable Development. Manila. 
6  A regional cooperation operations business plan does not exist. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities 
section of ADB’s website on 18 November 2020. 
7  ADB, the Asian Development Bank Institute, and the CAREC Institute also signed a cooperation agreement in 2017 
that provides a framework for sharing knowledge, undertaking joint workshops and seminars, organizing staff 
exchanges, and cofinancing research and capacity development. 
8  The CAREC Institute has established research teams in the research division and the chief economist’s unit, among 
others. It has introduced a quality assurance process, including a publication policy and an external review board.

2      
 
4.  The CAREC Institute is still at an early stage of development in becoming a reputable 
regional think tank. Its in-house expertise needs to be deepened and it needs to devise ways to 
meet its aspirations with limited resources. The CAREC Institute should also build up its brand 
and reputation in a systemic yet gradual way, through the development of a few key (“flagship”) 
products and activities and gradual expansion to other carefully selected areas. The following key 
needs and challenges are identified. 
 
5.  Adjusted vision for the Institute. The future of the CAREC Institute—its relevance, 
reputation, and place in an increasingly competitive landscape—depends on its ability to provide 
unique, tailored, and world-quality KPS on the emerging needs and challenges related to RCI in 
the CAREC region. The ongoing midterm review of the CAREC Institute Strategy, 2018–2022,9 
while evaluating its implementation from 2018 to 2020, is adopting a more forward-looking 
approach and vision, adjusting them to the changing realities and evolving demands.10 
 
6.  Quality of knowledge products and services. Enhancing the quality of KPS is at the 
core of many issues facing the CAREC Institute. Together with increased responsiveness of the 
CAREC Institute’s knowledge services to the needs of the CAREC countries, the enhanced 
quality of its KPS should lead to a better impact on policy making in the CAREC region, the 
CAREC Institute’s financial sustainability, brand recognition, and increased country ownership in 
the CAREC Institute.  
 
7.  Attraction of best talent and organizational issues. The single most important factor 
determining the quality of the CAREC Institute’s KPS is the quality of its staffing. Attracting 
talented staff has been a hurdle for the CAREC Institute. From 2016-2018, key positions were 
filled after lagging recruitment, and efforts to attract quality staff need to continue, through various 
means and channels.  
 
8.  Financial sustainability of the Institute. After 5 years of existence with a physical 
presence, the CAREC Institute remains heavily dependent on financing from the PRC and ADB. 
In the longer term, this is not a sustainable basis on which the CAREC Institute can expect to 
function. A key objective, therefore, is to expand and diversify the institute’s sources of funding.11 
Ongoing efforts for financial sustainability should be supported by prudent financial management 
arrangements. 
 
9.  The Institute in the post-COVID-19 world. The outbreak of COVID-19 has significantly 
altered economic and social lives in CAREC countries, and has affected the CAREC Institute’s 
activities.12 The CAREC Institute, with ADB assistance, has been adapting by developing an e-
platform for the learning management system and by contributing to the knowledge base on the 
 
9   CAREC Institute. 2018. CAREC Institute Strategy, 2018–2022. Urumqi. 
10  The midterm review considers the changing external landscape, including the unfolding COVID-19 crisis, as well as 
adjustments to CAREC Institute operations. It has involved consultations with a wide range of stakeholders, including 
the CAREC member countries, ADB, and the CAREC Institute’s Advisory Council. The midterm review is being 
transformed into an updated CAREC Institute Strategy that will extend to 2025. 
11  A completed exploratory assessment of the financial sustainability of the CAREC Institute in 2020 recommended 
several  key  actions  for  financial  resource  mobilization  and  complementary  actions  influencing  its  financial 
sustainability.  The  CAREC  Institute’s  Financial  Sustainability  Working  Group  discussed  the  proposed 
recommendations in September 2020, and they will be presented to the Governing Council in 2021.  
12 Many of the CAREC Institute’s planned projects could not be undertaken because of travel restrictions and 
quarantine regimes in CAREC countries, the diversion of the attention of government officials and the expert 
community to the COVID-19 crisis, and constraints on national budget resources.

3 
 
COVID-19 crisis in the region.13 The CAREC Institute will have to adapt its knowledge work and 
ways of functioning to the post-COVID world. It should strive to become a leader in the provision 
of virtual knowledge services in the region.  
 
10.  Country ownership. Interviews with a wide range of experts in the region have revealed 
that country ownership in the functioning of the CAREC Institute should be strengthened. Building 
greater country ownership and client demand will depend, significantly, on enhancing the quality 
of the CAREC Institute’s KPS, sharpening the focus and responsiveness of its knowledge service 
priorities, and improving the representativeness of its staffing. 
 
11.  Knowledge management. While the CAREC Institute has made efforts to improve its 
knowledge management in recent years, there is room for significant strengthening, including 
improvement of the CAREC Institute’s website, outreach to high-level policy makers in the region, 
engaging into strong partnerships with leading global and regional think tanks, and increasing the 
CAREC Institute’s overall visibility to a wider audience through an appropriate communication 
strategy. 
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  Solidifying its hard-earned gains in recent years, the TA will help the CAREC Institute 
refine its vision and business model, and entrench processes toward becoming a reputable and 
financially sustainable think tank in the CAREC region. The TA is aligned with the following impact: 
stronger regional cooperation among CAREC member countries based on high-quality policy 
dialogue and value-adding knowledge work realized (footnote 5). The TA will have the following 
outcome:  the  CAREC  Institute  functioning  as  an  independent  entity  delivering  high-quality 
knowledge services.14 The following three outputs will assist in achieving the impact and outcome. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
13.  Output 1: Institutional capacity and financial sustainability strengthened. This output 
will support further institutional development of the CAREC Institute to adopt its refined vision and 
strategy, and support the CAREC Institute’s functioning in the future as a reputable and financially 
sustainable regional think tank. Assistance under this output will be directed at (i) identifying and 
adopting  global  think  tanks’  institutional  best  practices,  (ii)  ensuring the  CAREC  Institute’s 
financial sustainability and resource mobilization,15 (iii) enhancing country ownership of the 
CAREC Institute, (iv) attracting and retaining talent, and (v) strengthening the CAREC Institute’s 
quality assurance process.16  
 
 
13 The CAREC Institute has launched studies assessing the impact of COVID-19 on the micro, small, and medium-
sized enterprises, and on the tourism sector in CAREC countries. A third study on vaccine perception in selected 
CAREC countries is in the preparation stage. Several COVID-related policy briefs were produced, and a series of 
webinars and knowledge sharing events were organized. 
14 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
15 Along with the implementation of the recommendations (footnote 11), the TA will undertake a financial management 
assessment of the CAREC Institute; and will prepare, train staff for, and implement, the resource mobilization 
strategy. 
16 In the past, and as a current practice, much of the quality assurance process involves a review by and advice from 
ADB staff. The TA will strengthen efforts to build a strong and efficient quality assurance process by the CAREC 
Institute, which is a key element for becoming a mature and respected knowledge institution.

4      
 
14.  In addition, this output will help address the CAREC Institute’s organizational challenges 
and issues, in line with its updated strategy. ADB assistance will help reinvigorate the work and 
deliberations of the CAREC Institute’s Governing Council and its Advisory Council to become 
more proactive in providing policy guidance to the CAREC Institute management and maintaining 
oversight of its performance and financial management. The TA will help establish a results-based 
framework and performance management system.17 It will also support the CAREC Institute’s 
transition from the current functional approach of planning and managing its knowledge activities 
separately through research, capacity building, and knowledge management, to a programmatic 
approach under which these activities are jointly deployed to support improved development 
policies, practices, and outcomes in CAREC member countries in well-specified priority program 
areas.  
 
15.  In the process, the relationship between ADB and the CAREC Institute will evolve to the 
next level as the CAREC Institute obtains more authority and accountability as an independent 
entity;  and  ADB,  aside  from  TA funding, focuses  increasingly  on  strategic  and  intellectual 
support.18  
 
16.  Output 2: Knowledge functions enhanced. The quality of the CAREC Institute’s work 
will be critical for distinguishing it from similar institutions, building up its brand, and enhancing 
country ownership. The CAREC Institute must place a premium on the quality of its KPS and 
remain focused on upgrading its research, capacity building, and knowledge management work. 
The TA will provide internationally recognized economic and technical expertise to assist the 
CAREC Institute in delivering top-notch knowledge products. The assistance will be directed at 
establishing strategic research planning and instilling a rigorous research culture, undertaking 
original  research  with  practical  policy  implications  for  member  countries,  and  ensuring the 
analytical independence that is a salient characteristic of reputable global think tanks.19   
  
17.  The ability to deliver relevant and high-quality KPS that promote RCI in the CAREC region 
should become the primary principle for selecting the CAREC Institute’s knowledge services and 
operational areas. This principle should lead to organic selectivity of the CAREC Institute’s 
knowledge services on a few core demand-driven areas, commensurate with its human, financial, 
and organizational resources.20 The TA will continue to support the CAREC Institute’s ongoing 
Visiting Fellow Program, strengthening its linkage with the work of CAREC’s sector coordinating 
committees and other channels to ensure policy relevance to and a close fit with CAREC 
 
17 The results-based framework will add, where possible, new innovative indicators and parameters to track the results 
of the CAREC Institute activities in a meaningful way. They could be based on the specific, measurable, achievable, 
relevant, and time-bound (SMART) system, and be linked to structural and financial decision-making processes. 
18 The TA will explore alternative mechanisms for the use of TA resources for engagement of consulting services by 
the CAREC Institute, whereby it could directly advertise and engage consulting services. ADB has already launched 
a capacity building program for the CAREC Institute on ADB’s principles and procedures for the recruitment of 
consulting services. ADB will also consider promoting the use of the CAREC Institute for project management, 
monitoring, capacity building, involvement of civil society etc., in its CAREC projects, including, potentially, on a fee-
for-service basis. 
19 As the CAREC Institute engages in research that strives to advance the RCI agenda in the CAREC region and 
produce objective analytics, its work should be shielded from political intervention. 
20 Examples of the emerging “flagship” areas and products include the CAREC Corridor Performance Measurement 
and Monitoring (CPMM) work, the CAREC Regional Integration Index, the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on the 
region and the need to “rebuild better,” and the digitalization agenda in CAREC. Currently led by ADB, the CPMM is 
being gradually transferred to the CAREC Institute through training and building of the CAREC Institute team’s 
expertise and experience on the subject.

5 
 
operations. The TA will also support refinements to the CAREC Institute’s capacity building and 
training program, adjusted for virtual delivery.21 
 
18.  Output 3: Knowledge management improved. The TA will assist the CAREC Institute 
in strengthening the dissemination of its KPS to policy makers in the CAREC region, with the aim 
of increasing the impact of these KPS on RCI-promoting policies, taking into account the changed 
ways that knowledge products are consumed.22 This output will support the development and 
dissemination of a new product, the CAREC Institute’s annual flagship report,23 as well as a 
carefully calibrated approach to virtual knowledge activities, communication, partnerships, and 
networking in the post-COVID-19 world. In addition, given the large regional knowledge and data 
gap, the TA will explore the creation of a regional multilingual data center at the CAREC Institute. 
The TA will continue providing support for access to various online resources, databases, and 
software required for knowledge services. The developed CAREC Institute’s communication and 
branding strategy will include new multilingual knowledge dissemination and outreach channels, 
including a revamped CAREC Institute website and a presence on popular virtual platforms, to 
extend outreach across the region and globally.24  
 
19.  The CAREC Institute has made significant progress in expanding its network among 
national research institutions in the region and beyond since 2015. The CAREC Think Tank 
Network  has  about  70  regional  think  tanks  and  universities,  and  the  annual  Think  Tank 
Development Forum has become an annual knowledge and experiences sharing event.25 The 
next stage of CAREC Institute development should evolve into mutually beneficial partnering with 
recognized organizations for the joint production of KPS, the attraction of knowledge project 
funding, and wider outreach.26  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, of which (i) $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6 and TASF-other sources) and 
(ii) $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Poverty 
Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund (PRC Fund) and administered by ADB.27 The key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
 
21 This involves designing programs for a larger number of beneficiaries as well as their convenience (e.g., taking 
training at a time of their choice and pacing their learning accordingly), designing proper certification, and other 
measures.    
22 For example, knowledge products could be packaged in bite-size information, extracting key messages; or through 
increased use of podcasts, dialogues in local languages, infographics, policy briefs, or mobile communication tools. 
23 The preliminary idea for the annual flagship report is to provide a yearly update on the regional integration index in 
the CAREC region, with a changing theme chapter each year. The proposed theme chapter for the inaugural 2021 
report is the impact of COVID-19 on the CAREC region in selected areas (e.g., the impact on micro, small, and 
medium-sized enterprises; tourism; or e-commerce).  
24 The CAREC Institute products will be also disseminated through various publications, the annual CAREC Think Tank 
Forum, research symposia, CAREC sector coordinating committees, and other CAREC channels. This TA will also 
support aligning the CAREC Institute’s communication and branding strategy with that of the CAREC Program. 
25 The forum brings together think tanks, academia, and governments to exchange views and share knowledge on 
evolving regional policy challenges. Up to five research grants are provided annually to support the joint research 
activities of the CAREC Think Tank Network. 
26 Establishing partnerships with leading global think tanks (and, potentially, a twinning arrangement with one of them), 
will be explored under the TA. Examples of global think tanks include the Asian Development Bank Institute, the 
Brookings Institution, the Center for Global Development, George Washington University’s Central Asia Program, 
and Harvard University’s Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies. 
27 The fund was originally named “People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund” in 
the 2005 Board paper. Application to the fund was made on 8 October 2020.

6      
 
21.  The PRC Fund will finance TA operational expenses in the form of consulting services 
and related goods and services, trainings, and conferences. The PRC Fund will not be used for 
(i) civil works, (ii) procurement of large-scale equipment, or (iii) permanent staffing costs. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA.  It  will  be  implemented  from  December  2020  to 
September 2023.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency;  and  the  Regional  Cooperation  and 
Operations Coordination Division of ADB’s Central and West Asia Department will be the TA 
supervising unit. As the implementing agency, the CAREC Institute will be responsible for the 
overall and day-to-day implementation of TA activities. The TA supervising unit will work closely 
with other ADB departments and relevant organizations to provide institutional and technical 
support to the CAREC Institute. ADB staff may act as resource persons at knowledge events and 
workshops,  with  travel  costs  charged  to  the  TA.  The  implementation  arrangements  are 
summarized in the table.

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
23.  Consulting services. The consulting services will be undertaken in two stages. Stage 1 
will engage resource persons who are experts on think tank management and RCI, under 
output 1, to review the CAREC Institute’s development, its current strategies, and plans for 
institutional development; and to advise on the CAREC Institute’s overall direction and on detailed

7 
 
work plans under this TA.28 Stage 2 will engage consulting services under the three outputs.29 
Based on the guidance of experts under stage 1, ADB will modify the indicative terms of reference 
in consultation with the CAREC Institute.  
 
24.  The consultants and resource persons under outputs 1 and 3 will be specialists in think 
tank  organization  and  functioning;  financial  sustainability  and  financial  management; 
organizational  efficiency;  knowledge  management;  and  information  and  communication 
technology, editing (English, Russian, Mandarin), and graphic design. Under output 2, reputable 
experts in economic development, RCI, and specific subject matter will be recruited to help 
establish strategic research planning, conceptualize and develop the research and capacity 
building products, and strengthen the peer review systems for the CAREC Institute’s publications. 
Experts will also provide advice to individual studies and knowledge service initiatives to help 
ensure their relevance and quality in design and implementation. A capacity building consultant 
will help the CAREC Institute further strengthen the virtual delivery of capacity building and 
training activities to improve their effectiveness and outreach. The consultants will also provide 
advice on academic research networking, including revitalizing the CAREC Institute Think Tank 
Network and the Think Tank Development Forum. 
 
25.  ADB will engage the consultants as individuals or firms following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.30  
 
26.  Cofinancier  requirements.  ADB  will  provide  the  PRC  Fund  with  periodic  reports 
(e.g., progress reports and additional updates on project implementation) and support the fund’s 
visibility as outlined in the PRC Fund Contribution Agreement (2017) and its implementation 
guidelines. For major changes in the project scope, duration, or funding arrangements, the TA 
team will circulate draft memos to the Partner Funds Division of ADB’s Sustainable Development 
and Climate Change Department for review before approval. Disbursement will follow the cost-
sharing principle, subject to the PRC Fund agreement and guidelines. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
27.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $1,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the People’s Republic of China 
Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not 
exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis for Supporting the Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation Institute, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
 
 
28 Stage 1 will determine whether a firm (e.g., a research institution, think tank(s), or a consortium) will be most effective 
and efficient for selected services or a package of services. In this case, a call for proposals will be announced for a 
bidding process on a competitive basis.  
29 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
30 During the TA implementation, ADB will explore the delegation of consultant recruitment to the CAREC Institute for 
selected tasks (for the CAREC Institute to become a contracting party), upon building its capacity in consultant 
recruitment (footnote 18).

Key Activities with Milestones  
Output 1: Institutional capacity and financial sustainability strengthened 
1.1. Engage international and national resource persons and consultants under stage 1 and stage 2 
(Q1–Q3 2021) 
1.2. Conduct a financial management assessment of the CAREC Institute and prepare a sustainable 
financing strategy/plan for CAREC Institute (Q1 2021 and Q4 2021) 
1.3. Develop a results-based framework to ensure high quality of deliverables (Q4 2021) 
1.4. Undertake institutional strengthening work (2021–2023) 
1.5. Conduct in-house trainings for CAREC Institute staff (2021–2023) 
Output 2: Knowledge functions enhanced 
2.1 Engage international consultants/experts to help identify core areas of focus for the CAREC 
Institute’s KPS (Q2 2021) 
2.2. Prepare research papers/studies in priority areas (2021–2023)  
2.3. Engage visiting fellows and experts for various CAREC research initiatives (2021–2023) 
2.4. Explore the establishment of a CAREC Institute regional data center (Q2 2022) 
 
Output 3: Knowledge management improved 
3.1. Engage communications and branding specialists to prepare a communication and branding 
strategy (Q4 2021) 
3.2. Explore partnerships (including, potentially, a twinning arrangement) with reputable think tanks 
(Q4 2021) 
3.3. Produce CAREC Institute knowledge products in digital format (2021–2023) 
3.4. Improve CAREC Institute website in new format, and disseminate knowledge products and services 
in innovative ways (2021–2023) 
TA Management Activities    
Recruitment of consultants, conduct of quarterly TA coordination meetings, review and evaluation of 
outputs, and preparation of project documentation on good practices and lessons learned. 
Inputs 
ADB: $1,000,000 ($775,000 TASF-6 and $225,000 TASF-other sources) 
People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund: $1,000,000 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, BAC = budget and audit committee, CAREC = Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation,  COVID-19 = coronavirus disease, CTTDF = CAREC Think Tank Development Forum, KPS = knowledge 
products and services, Q = quarter, RCI = regional cooperation and integration, TA = technical assistance, TASF = Technical 
Assistance Special Fund. 
a  ADB. 2017. CAREC 2030: Connecting the Region for Shared and Sustainable Development. Manila. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.

Note: The technical assistance (TA) is estimated to cost $2,000,000, of which contributions from the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) and the People's Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund are presented in 
the table.  
a  Financed by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6 and TASF-other sources). 
b  TA equipment includes information and communication technology hardware and software. This will be used for 
setting up the e-platforms or website maintenance (with hardware and software requirements). Equipment will be 
turned over to the CAREC Institute once the TA is completed. 
c  Includes translation and interpretation services, travel costs, and/or representation if ADB staff will act as resource 
persons in accordance with the 2013 memo on Use of Bank Resources: Regional TA and TA vs. Internal 
Administrative Expenses Budget. It will also include printing and associated costs for knowledge products on an 
exceptional basis, as endorsed by the ADB TA Administration Unit. 
d  Includes payments to service providers and contractors, logistics, and other related services; and other administrative 
support, including ADB staff travel when providing support services in the preparatory works, implementation, and 
administration of TA events and activities (travel and related costs for secretarial and administrative services).
